Others might stick with the same move, thinking their opponent expects them to change. Since both players chose paper last time, the opponent might expect us to switch to either rock or scissors. Statistical Analyst: From empirical studies, after a tie, players shift to the next move in the sequence (rock→paper→scissors→rock) about 30% of the time, stay with the same move about 35% of the time, and move to the previous move in the sequence about 35% of the time. If our opponent follows the most common pattern of staying with paper or shifting to scissors, scissors would be our best counter.

1) Stay with paper (expecting me to change)
2) Switch to scissors (the logical next move to beat repeated paper)
3) Switch to rock (if they think I'll switch to scissors)

Given these possibilities and the statistical tendencies shared, I think rock is our best move here. It would beat scissors if they make that logical shift, and tie with rock if they make the more defensive play.

Game Theorist: That's sound reasoning. Rock also protects against the scenario where they anticipate your thought process and choose scissors to counter your expected paper. The defensive rock choice covers the most probable opponent strategies based on the limited information we have.

Psychology Expert: I agree. Rock provides protection against the most likely move (scissors) while only losing to the less likely scenario of them sticking with paper twice in a row.
